log_name.description: The event log name. For example, syslog file name or Windows logging subsystem: Security.

log_provider.caption: Log Provider
log_provider.description: The logging provider or logging service that logged the event. For example, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing.

log_version.caption: Log Version
log_version.description: The event log schema version that specifies the format of the original event. For example syslog version or Cisco Log Schema Version.

logged_time.caption: Logged Time
logged_time.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

logged_time_dt.caption: Logged Time
logged_time_dt.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

loggers.caption: Loggers
loggers.description: An array of Logger objects that describe the devices and logging products between the event source and its eventual destination. Note, this attribute can be used when there is a complex end-to-end path of event flow.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.

modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time
modified_time_dt.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.

original_time.caption: Original Time
original_time.description: The original event time as reported by the event source.

processed_time.caption: Processed Time
processed_time.description: The event processed time, such as an ETL operation.

processed_time_dt.caption: Processed Time
processed_time_dt.description: The event processed time, such as an ETL operation.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product that reported the event.

profiles.caption: Profiles
profiles.description: The list of profiles used to create the event.

sequence.caption: Sequence Number
sequence.description: Sequence number of the event. The sequence number is a value available in some events, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the event time precision.

source.caption: Source
source.description: The source of an event is the data input from which it originates. In the case of data monitored from files and directories, the source consists of the full pathname of the file or directory. In the case of a network-based source, the source field consists of the protocol and port, such as UDP:514.

source_type.caption: Source Type
source_type.description: The source type of an event is the format of the data input from which it originates.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the event.

uid.caption: Event UID
uid.description: The logging system-assigned unique identifier of an event instance.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the OCSF schema, using Semantic Versioning Specification (SemVer). For example: 1.0.0. Event consumers use the version to determine the available event attributes.

metadata.caption: Metadata
metadata.description: The metadata associated with the event.
metadata.name: metadata

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the metric.

metric.caption: Metric
metric.description: The Metric object defines a simple name/value pair entity.
metric.name: metric

base_address.caption: Base Address
base_address.description: The memory address where the module was loaded.

function_name.caption: Function Name
function_name.description: The entry-point function of the module. The system calls the entry-point function whenever a process or thread loads or unloads the module.

load_type.caption: Load Type
load_type.description: The load type, normalized to the caption of the load_type_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source. It describes how the module was loaded in memory.

load_type_id.caption: Load Type ID
load_type_id.description: The normalized identifier of the load type. It identifies how the module was loaded in memory.

1.caption: Standard
1.description: A normal module loaded by the normal windows loading mechanism i.e. LoadLibrary.

2.caption: Non Standard
2.description: A module loaded in a way avoidant of normal windows procedures. i.e. Bootstrapped Loading/Manual Dll Loading.

3.caption: ShellCode
3.description: A raw module in process memory that is READWRITE_EXECUTE and had a thread started in its range.

4.caption: Mapped
4.description: A memory mapped file, typically created with CreatefileMapping/MapViewOfFile.

5.caption: NonStandard Backed
5.description: A module loaded in a non standard way. However, GetModuleFileName succeeds on this allocation.

start_address.caption: Start Address
start_address.description: The start address of the execution.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The module type.

module.caption: Module
module.description: The module object describes the load attributes of a module.
module.name: module

boundary.caption: Boundary
boundary.description:
The boundary of the connection, normalized to the caption of 'boundary_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary(same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

boundary_id.caption: Boundary ID
boundary_id.description:
The normalized identifier of the boundary of the connection.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary (same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

1.caption: Localhost
1.description: Local network traffic on the same endpoint.

10.caption: Gateway VPC
10.description: Through a gateway VPC endpoint (Nitro-based instances only)

11.caption: Internet Gateway
11.description: Through an Internet gateway (Nitro-based instances only)

2.caption: Internal
2.description: Internal network traffic between two endpoints inside network.

3.caption: External
3.description: External network traffic between two endpoints on the Internet or outside the network.

4.caption: Same VPC
4.description: Through another resource in the same VPC

5.caption: Internet/VPC Gateway
5.description: Through an Internet gateway or a gateway VPC endpoint

6.caption: Virtual Private Gateway
6.description: Through a virtual private gateway

7.caption: Intra-region VPC
7.description: Through an intra-region VPC peering connection

8.caption: Inter-region VPC
8.description: Through an inter-region VPC peering connection

community_uid.caption: Community ID
community_uid.description: The Community ID of the network connection.

direction.caption: Direction
direction.description: The direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email, normalized to the caption of the direction_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

direction_id.caption: Direction ID
direction_id.description: The normalized identifier of the direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email.

1.caption: Inbound
1.description: Inbound network connection. The connection was originated from the Internet or outside network, destined for services on the inside network.

2.caption: Outbound
2.description: Outbound network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the Internet or outside network.

3.caption: Lateral
3.description: Lateral network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the inside network.

flag_history.caption: Connection Flag History
flag_history.description: The Connection Flag History summarizes events in a network connection. For example flags ShAD representing SYN, SYN/ACK, ACK and Data exchange.

protocol_name.caption: Protocol Name
protocol_name.description: The IP protocol name in lowercase, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). For example: tcp or udp.

protocol_num.caption: Protocol Number
protocol_num.description: The TCP/IP protocol number, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). Use -1 if the protocol is not defined by IANA. See Protocol Numbers. For example: 6 for TCP and 17 for UDP.

tcp_flags.caption: TCP Flags
tcp_flags.description: The network connection TCP header flags (i.e., control bits).

uid.caption: Connection UID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the connection.

autonomous_system.caption: Autonomous System
autonomous_system.description: The Autonomous System details associated with an IP address.

domain.caption: Domain
domain.description: The name of the domain. See specific usage.

hostname.caption: Hostname
hostname.description: The fully qualified name of the endpoint.

instance_uid.caption: Instance ID
instance_uid.description: The unique identifier of a VM instance.

interface_name.caption: Network Interface Name
interface_name.description: The name of the network interface (e.g. eth2).

interface_uid.caption: Network Interface ID
interface_uid.description: The unique identifier of the network interface.

intermediate_ips.caption: Intermediate IP Addresses
intermediate_ips.description: The intermediate IP Addresses. For example, the IP addresses in the HTTP X-Forwarded-For header.

ip.caption: IP Address
ip.description: The IP address of the endpoint, in either IPv4 or IPv6 format.

location.caption: Detailed Geo Location
location.description: The geographical location of the endpoint.

mac.caption: MAC Address
mac.description: The Media Access Control (MAC) address of the endpoint.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The short name of the endpoint.

port.caption: Port
port.description: The port used for communication within the network connection.

subnet_uid.caption: Subnet UID
subnet_uid.description: The unique identifier of a virtual subnet.

svc_name.caption: Service Name
svc_name.description: The service name in service-to-service connections. For example, AWS VPC logs the pkt-src-aws-service and pkt-dst-aws-service fields identify the connection is coming from or going to an AWS service.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the endpoint.

vpc_uid.caption: VPC UID
vpc_uid.description: The unique identifier of the Virtual Private Cloud (VPC).

network_endpoint.caption: Network Endpoint
network_endpoint.description: The network endpoint object describes source or destination of a network connection.
network_endpoint.name: network_endpoint

hostname.caption: Hostname
hostname.description: The hostname associated with the network interface.

ip.caption: IP Address
ip.description: The IP address associated with the network interface.

mac.caption: MAC Address
mac.description: The MAC address of the network interface.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the network interface.

namespace.caption: Namespace
namespace.description: The namespace is useful in merger or acquisition situations. For example, when similar entities exists that you need to keep separate.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The type of network interface.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which may contain a data source specific value.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier for the network interface.

network_interface.caption: Network Interface
network_interface.description: The network interface object describes the type and associated addresses of a network interface.
network_interface.name: network_interface

svc_name.caption: Service Name
svc_name.description: The name of the proxy service.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the proxy.

network_proxy.caption: Network Proxy
network_proxy.description: The network proxy object describes a network proxy.
network_proxy.name: network_proxy

bytes.caption: Total Bytes
bytes.description: The total number of bytes (in and out).

bytes_in.caption: Bytes In
bytes_in.description: The number of bytes sent from the destination to the source.

bytes_out.caption: Bytes Out
bytes_out.description: The number of bytes sent from the source to the destination.

packets.caption: Total Packets
packets.description: The total number of packets (in and out).

packets_in.caption: Packets In
packets_in.description: The number of packets sent from the destination to the source.

packets_out.caption: Packets Out
packets_out.description: The number of packets sent from the source to the destination.

network_traffic.caption: Network Traffic
network_traffic.description: The object describes network data traffic. Network traffic refers to the amount of data moving across a network at a given point of time.
network_traffic.name: network_traffic

object.caption: Object
object.description: An unordered collection of attributes. It defines a set of attributes available in all objects. It can be also used as a generic object to log objects that are not otherwise defined by the schema.
object.name: object

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the observable attribute. For example: file.name.

reputation.caption: Reputation Scores
reputation.description: Contains the original and normalized reputation scores.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The observable value type name.

1.caption: Hostname
1.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Unique name assigned to a device connected to a computer network. A domain name in general is an Internet address that can be resolved through the Domain Name System (DNS). For example: r2-d2.example.com.

10.caption: Resource UID
10.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Resource unique identifier. For example, S3 Bucket name or EC2 Instance ID.

2.caption: IP Address
2.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Internet Protocol address (IP address), in either IPv4 or IPv6 format.

20.caption: Endpoint
20.description:
Observable by Object.
The endpoint object describes an addressable entity that has name and IP address.

21.caption: User
21.description:
Observable by Object.
The user object describes the identity of a user.

22.caption: Email
22.description:
Observable by Object.
The Email object describes the email metadata such as sender, recipients, and direction.

23.caption: Uniform Resource Locator
23.description:
Observable by Object.
The Uniform Resource Locator (URL) object describes the path and reputation of a URL.

24.caption: File
24.description:
Observable by Object.
The file object describes files, folders, links and mounts, including the reputation information, if applicable.

25.caption: Process
25.description:
Observable by Object.
The process object describes a running instance of a launched program.

26.caption: Geo Location
26.description:
Observable by Object.
The location object describes a geographical location, usually associated with an IP address.

27.caption: Container
27.description:
Observable by Object.
The Container object describes a specific container, which is a source of events. A Docker container is a lightweight, standalone, executable package of software that includes everything needed to run an application: code, runtime, system tools, system libraries and settings.

28.caption: Registry Key
28.description:
Observable by Object.
The registry key object describes a Windows registry key.

29.caption: Registry Value
29.description:
Observable by Object.
The registry value object describes a Windows registry value.

3.caption: MAC Address
3.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Media Access Control (MAC) address. For example: 18:36:F3:98:4F:9A.

34.caption: Account Object: name
34.description:
Observable by Object-Specific Attribute.
Object-specific attribute "name" for the Account Object.

35.caption: Account Object: uid
35.description:
Observable by Object-Specific Attribute.
Object-specific attribute "uid" for the Account Object.

4.caption: User Name
4.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
User name. For example: john_doe.

5.caption: Email Address
5.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Email address. For example: john_doe@example.com.

6.caption: URL String
6.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Uniform Resource Locator (URL) string. For example: http://www.example.com/download/trouble.exe.

7.caption: File Name
7.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
File name. For example: text-file.txt.

8.caption: File Hash
8.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
File hash. A unique value that corresponds to the content of the file.

9.caption: Process Name
9.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
Process name. For example: Notepad.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The observable data type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which may contain data source specific value.

value.caption: Value
value.description: The value associated with the observable attribute. The meaning of the data depends on the observable type.

observable.caption: Observable
observable.description: The observable object is a pivot element that contains related information found in many places in the event.
observable.name: observable

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the organization. For example, Widget, Inc.

ou_name.caption: Org Unit Name
ou_name.description: The name of the organizational unit, within an organization.  For example, Finance, IT, R&D

ou_uid.caption: Org Unit ID
ou_uid.description: The alternate identifier for an entity's unique identifier. For example, its Active Directory OU DN or AWS OU ID.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the organization. For example, its Active Directory or AWS Org ID.

organization.caption: Organization
organization.description: The Organization object describes characteristics of an organization or company and its division if any.
organization.name: organization

country.caption: Country
country.description: The operating system country code, as defined by the ISO 3166-1 standard (Alpha-2 code). For the complete list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 codes.

cpu_bits.caption: CPU Bits
cpu_bits.description: The cpu architecture, the number of bits used for addressing in memory. For example: 32 or 64.

edition.caption: OS Edition
edition.description: The operating system edition. For example: Professional.

lang.caption: Language
lang.description: The two letter lower case language codes, as defined by ISO 639-1. For example: en (English), de (German), or fr (French).

name.caption: Name
name.description: The operating system name.

sp_name.caption: OS Service Pack
sp_name.description: The name of the latest Service Pack.

sp_ver.caption: OS Service Pack Version
sp_ver.description: The version number of the latest Service Pack.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The type of the operating system.

type_id.caption: Type ID
type_id.description: The type identifier of the operating system.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which may contain a data source specific value.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the OS running on the device that originated the event. For example: "Windows 10", "OS X 10.7", or "iOS 9".

os.caption: OS
os.description: The OS object describes an operating system, such as Linux or Windows.
os.name: os

architecture.caption: Architecture
architecture.description: Architecture is a shorthand name describing the type of computer hardware the packaged software is meant to run on.

epoch.caption: Epoch
epoch.description: The software package epoch. Epoch is a way to define weighted dependencies based on version numbers.

license.caption: Software License
license.description: The software license applied to this package.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The software package name.

release.caption: Software Release Details
release.description: Release is the number of times a version of the software has been packaged.

package.caption: Software Package
package.description: The package object describes details about a software package.
package.name: package

class.caption: Class
class.description: The class of the peripheral device.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the peripheral device.

type.caption: Peripheral Device Type
type.description: The Peripheral Device type, normalized to the caption of the type_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the source.

type_id.caption: Peripheral Device Type ID
type_id.description: The normalized peripheral device type ID.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The peripheral device type is unknown.

1.caption: External Storage
1.description: The peripheral device is an external storage device.

2.caption: Keyboard
2.description: The peripheral device is a keyboard.

3.caption: Mouse
3.description: The peripheral device is a mouse.

4.caption: Printer
4.description: The peripheral device is a printer.

5.caption: Monitor
5.description: The peripheral device is a monitor.

6.caption: Microphone
6.description: The peripheral device is a microphone.

7.caption: Webcam
7.description: The peripheral device is a webcam.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The peripheral device type is not mapped. See the type attribute which contains an event source specific value.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the peripheral device.

vendor_id_list.caption: Vendor ID List
vendor_id_list.description: The list of vendor IDs for the peripheral device.

vendor_name.caption: Vendor Name
vendor_name.description: The primary vendor name for the peripheral device.

peripheral_device.caption: Peripheral Device
peripheral_device.description: The peripheral device object describes the identity, vendor and model of a peripheral device.
peripheral_device.name: peripheral_device

name.caption: Name
name.description: The policy name. For example: IAM Policy.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: A unique identifier of the policy instance.

policy.caption: Policy
policy.description:
The policy object describes the policies that are applicable.

Policy attributes provide traceability to the operational state of the security product at the time that the event was captured, facilitating forensics, troubleshooting, and policy tuning/adjustments.
policy.name: policy

cmd_line.caption: Command Line
cmd_line.description: The full command line used to launch an application, service, process, or job. For example: ssh user@10.0.0.10. If the command line is unavailable or missing, the empty string '' is to be used

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The time when the process was created/started.

created_time_dt.caption: Created Time
created_time_dt.description: The time when the process was created/started.

integrity.caption: Integrity
integrity.description: The process integrity level, normalized to the caption of the direction_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source (Windows only).

integrity_id.caption: Integrity Level
integrity_id.description: The normalized identifier of the process integrity level (Windows only).

lineage.caption: Lineage
lineage.description: The lineage of the process, represented by a list of paths for each ancestor process. For example: ['/usr/sbin/sshd', '/usr/bin/bash', '/usr/bin/whoami']

loaded_modules.caption: Loaded Modules
loaded_modules.description: The list of loaded module names.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The friendly name of the process, for example: Notepad++.

parent_process.caption: Parent Process
parent_process.description: The parent process of this process object. It is recommended to only populate this field for the first process object, to prevent deep nesting.

pid.caption: Process ID
pid.description: The process identifier, as reported by the operating system. Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

sandbox.caption: Sandbox
sandbox.description: The name of the containment jail (i.e., sandbox). For example, hardened_ps, high_security_ps, oracle_ps, netsvcs_ps, or default_ps.

session.caption: User Session
session.description: The user session under which this process is running.

terminated_time.caption: Terminated Time
terminated_time.description: The time when the process was terminated.

terminated_time_dt.caption: Terminated Time
terminated_time_dt.description: The time when the process was terminated.

tid.caption: Thread ID
tid.description: The Identifier of the thread associated with the event, as returned by the operating system.

uid.caption: Process UID
uid.description: A unique identifier for this process assigned by the producer (tool).  Facilitates correlation of a process event with other events for that process.

user.caption: User
user.description: The user under which this process is running.

xattributes.caption: Extended Attributes
xattributes.description: An unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs that represent a process extended attribute.

process.caption: Process
process.description: The process object describes a running instance of a launched program.
process.name: process

feature.caption: Feature
feature.description: The feature that reported the event.

lang.caption: Language
lang.description: The two letter lower case language codes, as defined by ISO 639-1. For example: en (English), de (German), or fr (French).

name.caption: Product Name
name.description: The name of the product.

path.caption: Product Path
path.description: The installation path of the product.

uid.caption: Product ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the product.

vendor_name.caption: Vendor Name
vendor_name.description: The name of the vendor of the product.

version.caption: Product Version
version.description: The version of the product, as defined by the event source. For example: 2013.1.3-beta.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product object describes a software product.
product.name: product

is_system.caption: System
is_system.description: The indication of whether the object is part of the operating system.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The time when the registry key was last modified.

modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time
modified_time_dt.description: The time when the registry key was last modified.

path.caption: Path
path.description: The full path to the registry key.

security_descriptor.caption: Security Descriptor
security_descriptor.description: The security descriptor of the registry key.

registry_key.caption: Registry Key
registry_key.description: The registry key object describes a Windows registry key.
registry_key.name: registry_key

data.caption: Data
data.description: The data of the registry value.

is_default.caption: Default Value
is_default.description: The indication of whether the value is from a default value name. For example, the value name could be missing.

is_system.caption: System
is_system.description: The indication of whether the object is part of the operating system.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The time when the registry value was last modified.

modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time
modified_time_dt.description: The time when the registry value was last modified.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the registry value.

path.caption: Path
path.description: The full path to the registry key, where the value is located.

type.caption: Type
type.description: A string representation of the value type as specified in Registry Value Types.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which may contain a data source specific value.

registry_value.caption: Registry Value
registry_value.description: The registry value object describes a Windows registry value.
registry_value.name: registry_value

product_uid.caption: Product Identifier
product_uid.description: The unique identifier of the product that reported the related event.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The type of the related event. For example: Process Activity: Launch.

type_uid.caption: Type ID
type_uid.description: The unique identifier of the related event type. For example: 100701.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the related event.

related_event.caption: Related Event
related_event.description: Related Event object describes event related to a finding or detection as identified by the security product.
related_event.name: related_event

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the remediation strategy.

kb_articles.caption: Knowledgebase Articles
kb_articles.description: The KB article/s related to the entity

remediation.caption: Remediation
remediation.description: The Remediation object describes details about recommended remediation strategies.
remediation.name: remediation

base_score.caption: Reputation Score
base_score.description: The reputation score as reported by the event source.

provider.caption: Provider
provider.description: The provider of the reputation information.

score.caption: Reputation Score
score.description: The reputation score, normalized to the caption of the score_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

2.caption: Safe
2.description: Consistently good behavior.

3.caption: Probably Safe
3.description: Reasonable history of good behavior.

4.caption: Leans Safe
4.description: Starting to establish a history of normal behavior.

5.caption: May not be Safe
5.description: No established history of normal behavior.

6.caption: Exercise Caution
6.description: Starting to establish a history of suspicious or risky behavior.

7.caption: Suspicious/Risky
7.description: A site with a history of suspicious or risky behavior. (spam, scam, potentially unwanted software, potentially malicious).

99.caption: Other
99.description: The reputation score is not mapped. See the rep_score attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

reputation.caption: Reputation
reputation.description: The object conveys the reputation/risk score of an entity (e.g. device, user, domain).
reputation.name: reputation

flags.caption: Flags
flags.description: The list of communication flags, normalized to the captions of the flag_ids values. In the case of 'Other', they are defined by the event source.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique request identifier.

request.caption: Request Elements
request.description: Request Elements details information pertaining to the API requests
request.name: request

account_uid.caption: Account UID
account_uid.description: The unique identifier of the account that owns the resource (e.g. AWS Account ID).

cloud_partition.caption: Cloud Partition
cloud_partition.description: The canonical cloud partition name to which the region is assigned (e.g. AWS Partitions: aws, aws-cn, aws-us-gov).

device.caption: Device
device.description: The device specific details, if the resource is a host/device.

group_name.caption: Group Name
group_name.description: The name of the group that the resource belongs to.

labels.caption: Labels
labels.description: The list of labels attached to an event, object, or attribute.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the resource.

owner.caption: Owner
owner.description: The identity of the service or user account that owns the resource

type.caption: Type
type.description: The type of the resource.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the resource.

resource.caption: Resource
resource.description: Describes details about resources that were affected by the activity/event.
resource.name: resource

code.caption: Response Code
code.description: The numeric response sent to a request.

flags.caption: Flags
